notes:
SHARON SHARALYKE


Dear Ms. Anwuzia, 

My uncle Rudy was in a terrible car accident on his way to the Western Union
office, and is in the hospital. I do not know when he will come home, but he
has asked me to write you and let you know what happened. When he does return
home, he will write to you. 

Johnson Baker has all the detailed information, which I am sure he will give
you. 

This probably puts a big obstacle in your way, but some things are unavoidable.

Sorry for the delay. 

Sharon Sharalyke

messages.body:
Dear Johnson Baker: 

I do not understand the content of your mail, which I received this morning. 

Please be so kind as to provide me details of this fund, as I do not recall
having an account in your bank, though I hold title to several large accounts
in various banking institutuions worldwide. This account may well have slipped
from my memory, which happens infrequently, but I should hope that I remember
an account worth $8.5 million dollars! 

I would appreciate hearing from you as soon as possible. 

Thank you very much. 

R. A. Ynazwrykic

messages.body:
Johnson Baker, 

I won't send you a copy of my passport. I will tell you the reason is that I
cannot risk identity theft. It is a HUGE problem in this country, and probably
world-wide. My passport will remain in my safe, and when I travel, it will
remain in my suit pocket. Period. And no copies, either. 

If someone were to gain access to my passport, there is no telling what kind of
sensitive information could be acquired, and the potential losses to me would
be catastrophic!! I can't imagine you asking for such vital material. 

It should be enough for you to have my banking information, I will assume that
you will need the account number and routing/code/security information, as
well. 

Write when you see eye-to-eye with me on this. 

Did you neglect to read the sentence, "You can call me Rudy"??? It is not
necessary to use my full name when addressing your mail to me. 

Rudy Ynazwrykic 

RUDY

Rudy's niece writes of a calamity...

messages.body:
SHARON SHARALYKE

Dear Sir: 

My uncle Rudy asked me to write you, and let you know what has happened. 

He was on his way to the Western Union office, and was involved in a horrible
automobile accident, he was not at fault, but was broad-sided by a huge truck.
He was rushed to the hospital, and underwent major emergency surgery to save
his life. He had lost a large amount of blood, and suffered two broken legs, a
crushed pelvis, head injuries, and a broken shoulder, plus internal injuriess.
His left arm had to be amputated. It is a miracle that he survived! 

He was in a coma for 6 days, and just regained consciousness last evening. I am
amazed that he remembers anything at all, much less his business with you. He
seems to be making very good progress, but I do not know when he will come out
of the hospital. I am sure he will contact you when he returns home. 

I know this will delay your business transaction, but some things are just
unavoidable. He plans to sue the truck driver, and will no doubt be awarded a
large settlement. 

Thank you for your time and consideration. 

Sharon Sharalyke

()

messages.body:
To Delta Finance (UK) Limited 

attn: Bill Smith 

cc: Johnson Baker 

Sir: 

You write that I will need to send a promissory note in favor of your
institution. Is there a proper form to complete, so that all your records will
be in order, or should I simply make my own promissory note? 

Will I be required to post a bond securing this note? I understand Johnson
Baker has already posted the deed to his home, but am I expected to do the
same? I would not want Johnson Baker to lose his domicile, in the unpleasant
event that this business transaction might fail--I would hate to have that on
my conscience. 

Perhaps you will be so good as to provide a "master" (or some kind of
guideline) of this promissory note? 

I will be awaiting your reply. 

R. A. Ynazwrykic

Dear Raynaz A. Ynazwrykic,

We just received a fax Memo from Mr. John Boatang of our USA office advicing
that Anticipatory Approval has been obtained and a financial instrument will be
issued in your favour and sent out to your address.

Our principal Insurance Company has further adviced our USA office that
Insurance Coverage be put in place before final draw-down on this loan, as we
need to secure this loan against default.

We advice that you arrange 5% Insurance Credit Bond Performance Coverage Fee to
Delta Finance. Due to limited time as expressed by your associate, we advice
you send this fee (US$1,115) via Western Union Money Transfer, as it will take
a long time for the bank to confirm receipt of this payment into the account of
our Principal Insurance Company, which will further delay the release of your
loan amount. As soon as this received, we shall further credit the Account of
our principal Insurance Company accordingly.

You are to use the name of our Chief Account Officer below to make the
transfer:

MR. MALCOLM WALES 
AMOUNT: US$1,115
COUNTRY: LONDON

Immediately this is done, kindly furnish us withnthe details of the transfer
accordingly, to enable us reconfirm with the Insurance Company and dispatch
your certified cheque of US$22,300.00 immediately. We shall further advise you
with the FEDEX tracking details for the shipment, alongside all neccessary
Insurance Papers accordingly.

Please do not hesitate to contact us, if there is any area we could be of
further assistance.

Treat as urgent.

Regards,

Paul Adams.

messages.body:
A month ago, I received this message from one Paul Adams of Delta Finance
Limited: 

"...You are to use the name of our Chief Account Officer below to make the
transfer:

MR. MALCOLM WALES 
AMOUNT: US$1,115
COUNTRY: LONDON

Immediately this is done, kindly furnish us withnthe details of the transfer
accordingly, to enable us reconfirm with the Insurance Company and dispatch
your certified cheque of US$22,300.00 immediately. We shall further advise you
with the FEDEX tracking details for the shipment, alongside all neccessary
Insurance Papers accordingly..."

I wired the amount of $1,115.00 to Malcolm Wales, in London, England.

He never collected the money, so I have no idea what became of the $22,300.00
certified cheque.

Then I received the following from Adams:

"...In pursuance of our mail of yesterday, we write to inform you that we are
yet to received details of the transfer accordingly.

Meanwhile, we received a fax memo from Mr. John Baotang of our USA office,
requesting for a status up-date on this loan and further adviced that if by the
close of business today we do not receive advice from you, we may have no other
alternative than to put a hold on the entire loan process..."

This is subsequent to the $1,450.00 which I was about to send to Chidinwa Jean
Anwuzia, for her fees in processing the loan. As you may know, I was involved
in a very serious automobile accident, and lay in a coma for several days, and
lost my left arm and both legs were severely broken. It was horrific, and it's
a miracle that I survived. The insurance company has been pressuring me to
settle for $15 million dollars, but I think I can get more from them. After
all, when a person's ARM is shattered so badly that it must be amputated!
That's got to be worth a lot of money. 

There are so many people involved in this business, and it has taken so many
different twists and turns, I wonder how anybody can keep everything straight! 

Why only $350? Are you some kind of cut-rate shyster, just trying to cheat the
others? What is your story? 

Rudy Ynazwrykic

messages.subject: Another update--Oh, when will it end?
messages.body:
Dear Ibe Daniel:

I just returned to my office, and there was a message to contact a Mr. B.
Springsteen, (the Boss of the Western Union office here in Marvin Gardens), so
I called him back and he told me something that shocked me to my very soul!  He
told me of Nigerian advance-fee frauds, (he called them "419-scams") and told
me that I had nearly become a victim of one of the most popular ones!  

I was shocked, I tell you, SHOCKED, that the people I trusted to enter into
partnership would try to swindle me this way, and I went back to the office and
retrieved my money.  I'm glad I did, too, he showed me many, many examples of
such frauds.  I was completely taken aback!

Needless to say, our partnership is dissolved, and our communications are
absolutely ended.

Rudolph A. Ynazwrykic

P.S.  Just so you know, all this was just a big, fat lie on my part.  (Just
like YOU were lying to me!)

I'm not Rudy Ynazwrykic.

I'm not a man.

I don't live in Marvin Gardens, PA.

I don't have a "personal banker Dinty Moore"  That's the name of a canned-stew
food product in the USA.

I wasn't in a car crash.  No broken legs, no broken shoulder, no amputated arm.
 All made up.

Obviously, no insurance money, no Bernie the Attorney, no settlement.

Never went to Western Union.  

I knew you were a scammer all along, and all the made-up names you kept coming
up with--they were all you, weren't they?  Are they names of co-scammers, your
scamming buddies there in the Internet cafe, do you all go out for drinks after
your shift to compare notes and laugh about how much money you are trying to
get from unsuspecting victims?

It won't work with me, "Johnson"/"Alhaja Mohammed"Chidinwa"/"Malcolm
Wales"/"Daniel"/"Bintu"/"Adams"/"Baotang"--I'm on to you and your scam.  

Get a real job, and have a nice life.   
BUT! ...
